required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Lidocaine Sprayed on Hemodynamics During Endotracheal Intubation
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Lidocaine Sprayed on Direct Laryngoscopy and Trachea on Hemodynamics During Endotracheal Intubation

brief_summary.textblock: A previous study demonstrated topical lidocaine spray on the larynx and the trachea is effective in reducing hemodynamic response to laryngoscopy and endotracheal intubation. In clinical practice, blind oropharyngeal application of lidocaine without aiding direct laryngoscopy can not assured that sprayed lidocaine effectively reaches the larynx and trachea. Therefore, direct laryngoscopy should be necessary to reach topical lidocaine to correct sites. Unfortunately, direct laryngoscopy itself can affect hemodynamics during spraying lidocaine. In this study, we will investigate an effect of lidocaine sprayed on direct laryngoscopy and the tracheal mucosa on hemodynamic change throughout intubation.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Prevention

primary_outcome.time_frame: baseline, at laryngoscope insertion, 60s after laryngoscope insertion, during intubation, one, two, three min after endotracheal intubation

arm_group.description: 10% Lidocaine was applied to the laryngoscope blade and 0.9% normal saline was applied to the trachea.
0.9% normal saline was applied to trachea and laryngoscope blade in Group C.
0.9% normal saline was applied to the laryngoscope blade and 10% Lidocaine was applied on trachea.
10% Lidocaine was applied on laryngoscope blade and trachea.

intervention.description: 0.9% normal saline was applied to trachea and laryngoscope blade
10% Lidocaine was applied to the laryngoscope blade and 0.9% normal saline was applied to the trachea.
0.9% normal saline was applied to the laryngoscope blade and 10% Lidocaine was applied on trachea.
10% Lidocaine was applied on laryngoscope blade and trachea.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- aged 20-60 years,
- ASA groups I or II
Exclusion Criteria:
- ASA III or IV,
- hypertension,
- anticipated difficult airway, and
- severe coronary and cerebrovascular diseases
